Predicting Keystrokes using an Audio Side-Channel Attack and Machine Learning

For my MSc Computer Science research project, I studied the feasibility of an audio side-channel attack regarding ‘keystroke snooping’, in which an attack can utilise the emanation of a keystroke to predict a specific key (or passage of keys) being pressed.

A novel attack was presented in this research, which used cross-prediction techniques on a stereo array of microphones to increase keystroke recovery rate by 15% when compared to previous research papers. It was shown from my research that key classification using a cross-predicted Random Forest model can achieve up to 89% keystroke recovery rate from a 40-key classification problem. User experiments were also conducted, showing results as high as 85% keystroke recovery from contextual arguments typed by the user. In all cases, a combination of Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs) and Time-Difference of Arrival (TDoA) features were used as input features for the Random Forest classification model.

You can download my research thesis for a detailed overview of the processes used to recover and predict keystrokes. My GitHub includes the Python code used to create the keystroke separation and classification algorithms, which were used to produce the results in the research paper.
